Brewster, wife of Eugene Brewster, editor of Motion Picture Magazine, April 1919 Introduction Why fan magazines? Like so many before me, I was initially attracted to the Hollywood fan magazine by the covers. I was easily seduced by the vibrant colors and lush, oversized portraits, pri­ marily of actresses whose clear faces and bright eyes were hypnotizing. These women, especially from the 1920s and 1930s, were startlingly beautiful as they gazed out under­ neath the Photoplay title or, head turned and eyes half open, gave a sideways glance from Motion Picture Classic. Women with exotic and mysterious names like Nazimova, Pola Negri and Theda Bara beckoned, daring someone to pick up the magazine and leaf through the contents. So I did. First in second-hand bookstores, then thrift stores, I would find a pile of Modern Screen. Hollywood. Picture-Play or Movieland and look through them, surprised to discover there were whole lives inside. Each magazine con­ tained interviews with actors and actresses, behind-the-scene looks at studios and sets, a whole world of illusion and fantasy between the covers. As I spent more time studying the rich details of the photogravure portraits inside, examining the stills taken on old movie lots, even the posed "natural" shots of handsome men and beautiful women at work or in front of their large houses with expansive lawns, my curiosity was stirred. Who were these people so unabashedly putting their lives on display? When I skimmed the articles and read the gossip columns, I found myself getting hooked, pulled in by people, intimate yet unfamiliar. Strangely, I wanted to know who would be chosen for the lead in Ben Hur, Valentino or Novarro? How big was the studio bungalow that Norma Talmadge had built? What was it like to be at the opening of the Ambassador Hotel? It was then I understood the allure of the fan maga­ zines. They held magic in their pages. These periodicals brought the unobtainable within reach, literally putting it within one's grasp for ten or fifteen cents, a quarter. I was dumbfounded. Where had they gone? What happened to these powerful, beautiful publications? The more I thought about the fan magazines--and I could not shake them from my mind--the more I wanted to know. Who read them and why? Who published them and where? Who wrote for them and how? How many magazines were there and how did they differ? When did they start, and of course, where did they go? I have attempted, for the first time I believe, to answer these questions. In the process, a story emerged. A story that began with the inaugural issue of Motion Picture in February 1911 through the explosion of titles during the troublesome 1920s, the altered focus of the glamorous 193 0s, the gossip-littered and studio-controlled 1940s, up through the dawn of the tabloid-exposé era, ending with the Confidential libel and obscenity trials in the 1950s. Fan magazines during this final decade went from covering fables and legends to exploiting the unfortunate and insecure, a harsh change from which neither the fans nor the magazines ever really recovered. This study examines the magazines from different angles : from the people who read them to the stars about whom they read; from the people who wrote for the magazines to the publishers and editors for whom they worked. It looks at the many devices used by the magazines to secure "inside informa­ tion" as well as the various methods employed to encourage the loyalty of subscribers. This work also explores the people whose lives were changed by the magazines, the in­ fluences the publications had on readers, writers and actors alike. Additionally, this study investigates the ways in which the magazines had to reinvent themselves over time in order to survive the shifting attitudes and mores within society and the film community. Fan magazines played an important role in American cultural history. They entertained at the same time they influenced American values. These publications are the precursors of some of the most popular titles today, from People to Vanity Fair to tabloids like the National Enquirer. Documented in the pages of the early fan magazines is the beginning of an American obsession with matinee idols that eventually transformed into a world-wide fascination with all forms of celebrity. Fan magazines, and the people that wrote for them, played a significant role in American film history. Who and what they promoted--or ignored--often determined whether or not a given film or star would be a success. A close look at their influences reveal innovative efforts to build and sustain an enormous readership while simultaneously shaping an entire industry. The publications, after all, were unique entities with deep but informal ties to the expanding and ever-changing business of producing motion pictures. As we shall see, they evolved from promotional tools, propagandis- tic advertisements really, to become what readers wanted. The magazines grew to both inform and entertain a great deal of, the American public at a time when readers could not get enough details about their beloved new recreation, the movies, and particularly about their new heroes and heroines, the movie actors and actresses. Photoplay, one of only two magazines devoted to film in 1913, had a circulation of seventeen thousand. By 1936 Daily Variety estimated that fifteen million people--nearly twelve percent of the American population--read approximately twenty-five different fan magazines in the United States. Ten years later Atlantic put the figure of fan magazine readership as high as forty-five million.^ Whatever the figures, one thing is certain : an enormous number of people focused on one topic--the appeal of movie stars--and for decades, fan magazines were the sole delivery agents. Frequently the publications are referred to as a common indistinguishable form, usually deridingly, once in a while deservedly; they had their ignoble moments. But if my investigations have proven anything, I believe it is that while fan magazines definitely deserve a category of their own, the periodicals themselves retain individual, identifi­ able characteristics. There are differences, subtle and large, among titles and certainly between appearances, style and coverage across the decades. Collectively the fan magazines were in a sense a reflection of our society. Studying their evolution reveals significant changes in American social history. In that they consistently requested and received feedback from their readership, the successful magazines became what the public wanted. Publishers and editors adjusted their coverage, and their opinions and editorials often stood in sharp contrast to the daily newspapers and later gossip columnists. Moreover they began a process that for better or worse is continued today. The way in which society has turned everyone from professional athletes and recording artists to politicians and painters into celebrities--indeed the way that anyone whose life has brushed these same individuals and has become famous on that basis alone--all began long ago with the idolization captured by the fan magazine. It was not what was intended, but it is the result, making the fan magazines a record of who we were as well as what we would become. And so the story of these unique publications, their development and eventual demise, is of as much relevance today as ever, for the fan magazines constructed and dis­ played American myths. And while few complete runs of all titles have been preserved by libraries or private collec­ tors, happily a number of copies of fan magazines have been saved, enough that they--as with the movies they celebrate-- may continue to fascinate, intrigue, and take us away. Prologue Setting the Stage: The Trust vs. Independents Vitascope to Vitagraph Not yet twenty, James Stuart Blackton set off from Sheffield, England, in 1895 for the exciting new world of New York City. Born to a poor family, the former carpenter's apprentice had not yet made up his mind about what he wanted to do with his life, but he knew that the life of a laborer was not for him.^ A handsome man with dark hair and intense eyes, Blackton had artistic ambitions that went unappreciated in his home town, where most men worked long hours in quarries and mines for a decent day's wage. Aspiring to more, and with the optimism and energy of youth, Blackton set sail for America, convinced that grand opportunities awaited him. He immediately landed a job as a freelance reporter for the New York (Evening) World, covering whatever stories he could dig up and sell to the editor. Paid by the inch, he often submitted sketches with his text, to get that much more money out of the paper. While digging for stories, the young man learned of a new machine said to 7 project a "moving image," invented by Thomas Edison. To find out more about the device, Blackton set off to interview Edison in his West Orange, New Jersey, studio. There, the young man amused the inventor with his drawings, including a sketch the young reporter did of Edison himself.^ In turn, Blackton was smitten with Edison's new machine, a film projector that was a derivative of his prior inven­ tion, the Kinetograph, combined with technology developed by others. Edison called his projector the Vitascope. Smitten, Blackton brashly asked to purchase one but was told by the inventor that due to complicated patent restrictions, his company was only able to lease the machines at present. Soon, however, he would be releasing for sale a new model called the Edison Projecting Kinetoscope. Edison promised to notify Blackton when the new projector was available and made good on his word, selling him Edison projector Number Thirteen in November 1896.^ By this time, Blackton had developed a friendship with Albert E. Smith, a budding financier originally from Kent, England. The two examined their new projector, eventually figuring out how to rig the machine to do double-duty as a camera, and the Vitascope became what they called a Vita­ graph. The men began filming first Blackton's drawings, then each other and soon, events like the burning of the Windsor Hotel. They offered their films to local theaters that were popping up in small storefronts on street corners throughout New York City. These theaters, becoming more and more 8 popular among working class folks, were known as "nickelo­ deons, " after the price of admission they charged to display short novelty films.'^ In 1899, Blackton and Smith accepted William T. "Pop" Rock into their organization, formally incorporating their enterprise as American Vitagraph Company. Recognizing that there were hundreds of theaters, yet only a handful of film production companies, the three men and set out to make motion pictures. Elsewhere, similar motion picture produc­ tion companies were being established by others, including Sigmund Lubin in Philadelphia and Colonel William N. Selig in Chicago.^ Trials to Trust Edison's lawyers, meanwhile, were busy filing lawsuits in an attempt to protect the inventor's U.S. patent number 589,168. Their argument was that since Edison had sold no cameras, any picture made by anyone else was an infringement on his invention. In July 1898, the Edison company had half a dozen lawsuits pending when they sued Vitagraph.^ Since the two men had a prior relationship, Blackton initially was able to strike a bargain with Edison, allowing Vitagraph to continue filming, while providing Edison with the control of all negatives. This would allow Edison's company to sell prints and collect royalties on films made by Vitagraph. The arrangement satisfied Edison and his lawyers for the next eight or nine years, until other companies began requesting similar deals on varying terms. Because Edison's lawyers were not interested in managing dozens of different term agreements with as many companies, they began in 1907 to formulate a standardized contract that was clearly not favorable to the film producers. To protect their interests, eight of the leading film manufacturers got together with west coast film distributor George Kleine (one of three founders of Kalem), and negotiated a settlement with Edison. The profits from the films would be split, with fifty percent going to Edison off the top, the other half divided by different fractions between the remaining members of the organization. By December 1908, membership was limited to the production houses of Edison, Vitagraph, Biograph, Kalem, Lubin, Selig, Essanay, Méliès, Pathé and George Kleine himself.^ The arrangement satisfied the members of the group, now formally organized as the Motion Picture Patent Corporation (MPPC), deridingly known as the "Trust." There remained, however, outside the MPPC, a small but vocal faction of independent production companies that were not satisfied. They claimed the technology they were using was not strictly based on Edison's patents, and thus were unwilling to enter into any profit-sharing agreement with Edison or the Trust. Trouble was brewing. The aim of the MPPC initially was to protect Edison's patent, but as time went on the members broadened their 10 interests and set out to monopolize the market. Restricting film production was one thing but the Trust would have even more control were it to regulate the distribution of films as well. With the number of nickelodeons rapidly increasing all over the country, the Trust began in 1909 to organize a network of film distributors--Imown as exchangemen--forcing them to rent MPPC films only to those exhibitors who would pay the Trust a license fee of two dollars a week. Small as it was, the theater license fee alone brought in over one million dollars a year in revenue for the Trust.® Taking advantage of their disorganized competitors, the MPPC was beginning to completely control motion picture product (the film companies), distribution (the exchangemen), and rental (the theaters). Left out in the cold of course, were the independent film makers, exchangemen, and exhibitors, whose numbers were nonetheless expanding. Several independent thinkers main­ tained that with the public's appetite for movies escalating, even the Trust could not keep up with the demand for more and more motion pictures. Many recognized that there was an opportunity to fight the MPPC, if the independents were to organize and provide a united front. But how? The independ­ ents, by definition, were a loose and diverse group. With so many different players coming and going, the independents as a whole presented little competition to the Trust. There were film companies like Rex, Powers, Thanhouser and Fox, each of whom relied on a different distribution 11 method to get their films to as many theaters as they could. But there were literally thousands of independent exhibitors scattered across the nation who frequently dealt with several exchangemen at once, as their only interest was in securing enough product to satisfy customer demand. Fed up with the disorganized methods of independent distribution channels, theater owners were increasingly inclined to pay the two- dollar license fee to the Trust just to guarantee receipt of a set number of films each week.^ One independent exhibitor in Chicago, however, refused to pay the fee. He was willing to gamble, and willing to fight. His name was Carl Laemmle. Immigrant to Independent Laemmle first came to America as a teenager in 1897 to escape the stifling future he was convinced he would face were he to remain in his small hometown in Germany near the Swiss border. A diminutive man--he was just over five feet-- Laemmle was nonetheless a scrappy fellow with ambition to make it big. Once in the United States, Laemmle tried his hand at various trades, becoming for a time a tailor's apprentice in New York City, a dairy farmer in Wisconsin before opening first one then two small storefront nickel­ odeons in Chicago in 1906.^® A few years later, when the Trust began applying pressure on him to join, Laemmle not only refused their offer, he did so with a vengeance. He set out to dismantle the Trust. The service networked several different production companies, providing much-needed organization to the distribution of independent films to independent theaters. To publicize his new venture, Laemmle proudly declared his independence from the Trust in April 1909 by placing ads in newspapers and trade periodicals.^^ Still, he was reliant on the erratic production schedules of the various independent film companies. Film production being a new field filled with novices, it was not unusual in the early days of filming for accidents on the set--fires and explosions were common--or problems in developing negatives to ruin the end-product. Laemmle figured that one way to guarantee his new company would have sufficient product to distribute would be to make it himself. Thus, Laemmle established his own film production company in October 1909, the origins of what today is known as Universal Studios. The MPPC, meanwhile, like the Edison company before it, was busy filing suit against any unlicensed company using technology similar to its patents, whether it was for recording or projecting film. Early on, many small companies could not afford to risk a legal battle against the well- funded trust and the majority acquiesced to the power of the MPPC, abandoning their companies or leaving the country. Laemmle, with incredible fortitude, nevertheless remained undaunted. He began taking out full-page advertisements in 13 trade journals taunting the Trust, hoping to provoke other exhibitors and independents into unity and action. Ads stating "Have you paid two dollars for a license to smoke your own pipe this week?" began showing up, sometimes accompanied by a figure Laemmle invented to lampoon the Trust, a severe looking "General Filmco."^® The MPPC retaliated by buying up as many exchangemen as they could, trying to weaken independent distribution channels. At the same time, the Trust began to edge out the foreign film market, making shipping and distribution difficult for exporters. The Laemmle Film Service, which had relied on foreign films to supplement their small amount of independent product, found itself facing further strain. Laemmle responded by simply producing more films. In 1909, he made a dozen; the next year his company made over one hundred motion pictures. Next, the MPPC negotiated with Eastman Kodak to secure an exclusive contract for raw film stock. Laemmle reacted by using his contacts in Europe to secure stock from overseas, distributing it himself. The Trust's relentless tactics, combined with Laemmle's rabble-rousing, began to encourage others to get involved. One independent exchangeman, William Fox, filed suit against the MPPC, charging conspiracy in restraint of trade. The movement picked up even more momentum when Laemmle folded his distribution company in with several other independents, forming the Motion Picture Distributing and Sales Company. Ten other independent 14 exchangemen joined forces, creating the Film Supply Company of America.^® The combination of the two independent distribution companies now represented more film production houses than the Trust. The gap was beginning to close and it started to show in the theaters as well. In early 1909, there were 2,500 independent theaters competing against 4,000 MPPC-licensed houses. By July 1911, the number of independents had risen to 6,298 versus 6,571 licensed theaters.^® Which group was to win, would depend upon who could best sell their product to audiences. The public, after all, was unaware of the behind-the-scene struggle for control of the growing motion picture industry; the audience simply wanted to see a good story. 15 Chapter One The Teen Years: Stories to Stars Birth of a Magazine When the first fan magazine appeared in February 1911, the American public was clamoring to enjoy the diversion of motion pictures, and they were doing so in droves. In 1907, two hundred thousand people a day were attending nickelodeons in New York state, with double that number on Sundays; by 1910, the numbers were up to nine hundred thousand a day in New York City alone.^ To shore up control of this increasingly lucrative market, J. Stuart Blackton, the head of Vitagraph, had come up with the idea to start a promotional magazine that would serve to publicize only the films of MPPC members. The Trust itself provided the one hundred thousand dollar start-up fee for the venture, with the understanding that each member would contribute two hundred dollars per feature highlighted in the magazine. ^ To pioneer the new monthly periodical, Blackton engaged the services of Eugene V. Brewster, an 16 attorney and former editor of short feature magazines from Long Island. As if to claim ownership of the entire cinematic art form, they called their venture Motion Picture Story Magazine. Approximately eight by ten inches in size, the first issue was one hundred and eighteen pages long and cost fifteen cents. The magazine was available for purchase in the lobbies of all MPPC-licensed theaters, soon to expand to newsstands nationwide. The public enthusiastically received the publication of Motion Picture Story Magazine, despite the fact that the first few issues featured little more than a series of narratives e:xpanding upon the stories of members's films . The masthead proclaimed that the magazine would feature in print the "most notable of the seventy or eighty stories presented each month" in film.^ The February 1911 issue of Motion Picture Story Magazine had over a dozen of these stories, each four to six pages in length. Many of the stories filmed by the Trust companies were derived from classic literature, often adaptations of the works of Tennyson or Shakespeare or Dickens. The stories in the magazine then, aimed to provide a condensed version of these tales by featuring stills from the motion pictures. The printed versions were "illustrated with photographs from life of these actors engaged in the presentation of the photoplay upon which the story is based.Just as librettos provide opera-goers with the text of a dramatic musical piece, these "fictionalizations" explained to an audience who 17 might be unfamiliar, the finer points of the saga being retold on the screen. With so many immigrants and working class people attracted to the new medium of motion pictures, the number of people needing such clarification were legion. Still, a large number of people attended motion pictures just to see a pretty face. The Mystery Girl In 1908, the Vitagraph Girl was a mystery. Every week, millions of fans across America crowded into nickelodeons to watch the silent films in which the magnetic dark-haired, wide-eyed beauty appeared. After following the actions of the on-screen heroine for about an hour, most viewers were left mesmerized. When the picture was over, many wanted to know: who was that girl? Vitagraph was not saying. Like the other film companies of the day, Vitagraph did not provide billing for performers' names. Since 1905 when the first nickelodeon opened, studios like Essanay, Kalem, Lubin, Selig, Thanhouser and Vitagraph presented their short films to the public by emphasizing the names of the produc­ tion companies themselves. The aim was to associate in the mind of the picturegoer the name of the studio with the action of the story, thus building a demand for a company's product. Among Trust companies, Vitagraph built its reputation as a purveyor of comedies and classics, while Selig emphasized stories set in the great outdoors.^ Not that feature players in films especially wanted 18 their names known. Several Broadway producers refused to hire those who worked in motion pictures. Specifically, the New York production team of Klaw and Erlanger were known to have openly blacklisted players in films, considering them as traitors, unworthy of returning to stage work after contri­ buting to the demise of legitimate theater by acting in motion pictures. An actor's anonymity was also convenient for motion picture production houses, the owners of which were leeiry of performers acquiring "names" for themselves ; renown might lead to the desire for higher wages.^ In advertisements, references to players were usually limited to phrases such as "artistically enacted by real actors," and when companies did receive requests for infor­ mation on particular artists, they were routinely ignored.^ With no other details to go by, the people and the press began referring to actors by the studios with which they were associated. Thus, there was the Biograph Girl, the Kalem Girl, and of course, the Vitagraph Girl. Although it would seem from the adoption of such nick­ names that these women held positions of high influence within their companies, the reality was that the Vitagraph Girl was a simple young woman from Flatbush, New York, named Florence Turner. She had dark wavy hair of medium length and large, expressive eyes which complimented her small mouth and tinier chin. Turner had absolutely no training in the arts and was attracted to work at the studio due more to its proximity to her parents' house, where she still lived, than 19 to any propensity she had for acting.® Perhaps it was this distinctive lack of glamour that the motion picture studios were shielding from an adoring public. Like most of the other members of the Vitagraph players in 1906, Turner pulled double duty: the Vitagraph Girl earned eighteen dollars a week as actress and wardrobe mistress. By comparison, members of the more financially sound Edison Stock Company averaged thirty dollars a week. Still, these figures were fairly high for the day; not until eight years later, in January 1914, would workers on the newly estab­ lished assembly lines of Ford Motor Company in Detroit earn twenty-five dollars a week.® The Dln^led Darling and the Vitagraph Girl Stage actors, of course, could not rely on a steady weekly income unless they were in production. Maurice Costello was a leading actor on New York stages when in the fall of 1909 he found himself between shows. The cinema was robbing theater audiences and the Broadway season was the worst in years. Faced with impressive debts from high living, he applied to play in the films of the Vitagraph Players Stock Company and was immediately hired. The rela­ tionship between studio and actor was rocky at first because Costello refused to work for the company as a carpenter building sets between shoots.10 An established actor of average build with blond curly 20 hair and prominent dimples, Costello immediately attracted a following through the new medium of film. When Vitagraph offered a long-term contract, he accepted only on condition: "I am an actor and I will act; I will not build sets and paint scenery."11 By 1910, Costello had gained a glowing reputation among picturegoers as "Dimples" or the "Dimpled Darling," prompting him to further push Vitagraph into publicizing his full name in the promotion of his pictures. They complied in early 1910 and Costello became the first motion picture actor to attain top billing.1^ A precedent had been set. A leading man requires a leading lady and so Vitagraph sought to combine their two best assets. The company transformed Florence Turner's image in order to pair her with Maurice Costello in films. Despite her lack of formal training. Turner had a unique ability to contort her face in many ways, winning equal regard for playing roles as young boys in comedies as well as old women. She gained prominence with each successive feature, but to be considered a romantic lead, Lawrence would need to be presented as a graceful and beautiful heroine. As part of the package, in May 1910, Vitagraph began presenting Turner's name on the screen alongside Costello's.13 With her transformed image and the audience now able to put a name to her face, marriage proposals by the thousands rolled in for Turner. There was an immediate demand for 21 personal appearances by the actress. Vitagraph responded by sending Turner on tour. Crowds crushed into her personal visits at "Vitagraph Nights," with droves of people being turned away from these special nights held across first New York, and then the country. A typical night began with Turner arriving in the Vitagraph touring car from which she dramatically exited and was led through a throng of admirers. Once inside, an introduction was given, often by the theater owner. Turner then briefly addressed the crowd who had not previously heard her voice. Invariably she included a statement about how fortunate she was to actually see her audience, after they had spent so many nights seeing her. Bouquets were thrown to her before Louise Githens Trimble would sing the Vitagraph Girl song, in a rich, contralto voicei^^ I'm in love with the Vitagraph Girl, The sweet little Vitagraph Girl, Each moment a picture of romance or hate. Her tragedy's bully, her love simply great. At the close of the song, the audience frequently demanded an encore and only when they were satisfied would Jean the Dog-- a Vitagraph fixture trained by Turner's good friend and future partner Larry Trimble--come out and do stunts on stage. Finally, a motion picture with Florence Turner was shown, and at its end, the star once again walked through the crowd to make her exit. This was true star treatment.
